reviewText:
I love these old movies.  When one of the actors talked about giving one of the boys carfare, I had to laugh.  We used to say that where I came from.
Tough kids with hearts of gold.  It never gets old.
It was impossible to tell as the movie froze 10 minutes from the end.

They never hoped for an Oscar, but wanted to entertain families with these films. Some are better than others, but I enjoy them all. I remember watching these on TV when I was a kid. I am sure these actors made very little money. I never heard about them in later years and often wondered what happened to them. There are many to choose from on Amazon Prime. They are not sophisticated, but contain minimal violence and no sex or drugs, etc. The kids are always trying for a better life, but stick together to help each other and their families and friends.
I always enjoyed the East Side Kids Movies when I was young. Harmless fun enjoyment.
Leo Gorcys caracter muggs is the gangs leader and the brain of the oufitt.the plot of the storys is not as important as much as the interactions of the gangs members, which are always fun.
I was expecting the Bowery Boys with Leo Gorcey and Huntz Hall. This is a similar genre, but not the one I wanted. My fault.
I still remember some shows.but they were on sundays & I would try to get out of sunday school if they were on

Just loved the one. have watched it many times.
found out we owned it. That's how good it is.
A good watch about the old days

This is the first of 22 pre-Bowery Boys Movies, 1940-1945, #2 through 14; and #16 are available, here at Amazon on the following collections: The East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 1 The East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 2: Pride of the Bowery/Flying Wild The East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 3 East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 4: Mr. Wise Guy/Let's Get Tough The East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 5 The East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 6 East Side Kids Double Feature, Vol. 7 These collections cover the series in-order --- like stated --- skipping THIS particular TITLE. The 15th movie (Mister Muggs Steps Out) is out of print. While this DOES have #16 (Million Dollar Kid), #17-22 are NOT available [either]. Skipping to Complete, so far, collections... highly recommend these: * The Bowery Boys: Volume One <=== Twelve, RESTORED, movies! * The Bowery Boys: Volume Two <=== Twelve MORE, restored, movies. Two in WIDESCREEN!

Very happy with it!

Million Dollar Kid, 1943 film

The film begins with the Brooklyn Bridge in the background. Muggers create crime in the neighborhood. Herbie wants to join their club (he is a cousin of Glimpy). Their chatter is humorous. Men at a pool hall spot a rich stranger and rob him in an alley. Muggs and the others rescue him. The police take them in for questioning. Courtland comes to identify them as his rescuers. [An "A" sticker was for gasoline rationing.] Courtland allows them to use his gym. A servant can be fired on a whim. The other servants leave in solidarity! Does his son Roy have a problem? Can the boys identify the muggers? We learn more about those muggers. Muggs and Glimpy learn more about that French soldier. Louise doesn't welcome bad news. Muggs has a plan to save Louise. It works!

A telegram from the War Department brings bad news for Courtlandt. Their doctor makes house calls. Roy and Muggs box in the gym. They form a plan to rescue Skinny from the bad guys, and bring the bad guys to the police. Muggs explains for Roy, there will be a happy ending. There is a joke in the last scene.

This story uses "juvenile delinquency" as the background for a comedy, as well as an imposter trying to marry into a wealthy family. Were servants readily available during wartime? However implausible this story, it provided entertainment during the 1940s. It has a message as a morality play. Do younger sons have a problem in matching their older brothers?
Ugh
Love oldies
Excellent family entertainment. A comedy film about a gang of youth.
Saw the East Side Kids movies when I was a kid and loved them.  They seem so corny to me now.
Great movies and more
